variant.question:
Landing Mass    35 000 kg
Flaps    VREF
15    140 kt
30    135 kt
45    130 kt
An airplane is planned to land with a landing mass of 35 000 kg and it is fitted with 200 psi tyres. What is the minimum recommended flap setting on a wet runway usable in order to minimize the risk of hydroplaning?

options.text: Any flap speed is above the hydroplaning speed.

variant.question:
During the certification flight tests regarding fuel jettisoning it must be shown that:
1) Fuel jettisoning system and its operation are free from fire hazard.
2) The fuel discharges clear of any part of the aeroplane.
3) Fuel fumes do not enter any part of the aeroplane.
4) The jettisoning operation does not adversely affect the controllability of the aeroplane.
The level to be used for jettison fuel should not be less than:

options.text: 1800 m / 6000 ft agl
1200 m / 4000 ft agl
1500 m / 5000 ft agl

variant.question: Where is it best to carry out fuel jettison?

options.text: Above flight level 60.
On final approach.
Over water if possible, below flight level 60.
In a holding pattern if cleared by ATC.

variant.question: The correct definition of a safe forced landing is:

options.text: an unavoidable landing or ditching with a reasonable expectancy of no injuries to persons in the aircraft or on the surface.
an inevitable landing on land or sea from which one may reasonably expect no injuries on board.
a landing on land or sea from which it is guaranteed no injuries will result to the occupants.
a voluntary landing on land or sea carried out by the crew in order to protect the aircraft and its occupants.

variant.question: The correct definition of a safe forced landing is:

options.text: An inevitable landing on land or sea from which one may reasonably expect no injuries on board or on the surface.
A landing on land or sea from which it is guaranteed no injuries will result to the occupants.
An inevitable landing on land or sea from which one may reasonably expect no injuries on board.
A voluntary landing on land or sea carried out by the crew in order to protect the aircraft and its occupants.

variant.question: The correct definition of a safe forced landing is:

options.text: an unavoidable landing or ditching with a reasonable expectancy of no injuries to persons in the aircraft or on the surface.
a landing on land or sea from which it is guaranteed no injuries will result to the occupants.
a voluntary landing on land or sea carried out by the crew in order to protect the aircraft and its occupants.
an inevitable landing on land or sea from which one may reasonably expect no injuries on board.

variant.question: State the reason for fuel jettison during an emergency after take-off.

options.text: To reduce the mass to Maximum Landing Mass.
An overweight aircraft may damage the runway if the PCN, pavement classification number, is lower than the ACN, aircraft classification number.
To improve airplane manoeuvrability and expedite return for landing.
It will reduce the risk of fire on landing.

variant.question: What is the reason for dumping fuel during an emergency after take-off?

options.text: To get below maximum landing mass (MLM)
To have a better airplane manoeuvrability and get back to the airport quickly for landing.
Lower risk of fire during landing.
To not damage the runway while landing.

variant.question: The height below which an aeroplane should not jettison fuel is:

options.text: 1800 m / 6000 ft above ground.
1200 m / 4000 ft above ground.
3000 m / 10000 ft above ground.
1500 m / 5000 ft above ground.

variant.question: A four-jet aircraft must be equipped with an in-flight fuel jettisoning system in order to reduce the aircraft weight in an emergency:

options.text: Unless it is capable of meeting the climb requirements : 2.7% in approach configuration with 1 engine inoperative and 3.2% in landing configuration with all engines operative
Until the central tank is empty in order to cope with the wing and landing gear constraints at landing touchdown
In order to reach the maximum structural landing weight in less than 15 minutes after activation of the jettisoning system
In order to reduce the landing distance to 60% of the effective runway length

variant.question: A four-engined jet aircraft must be equipped with an in-flight fuel jettisoning system in order to reduce the aircraft weight in an emergency:

options.text: unless it is capable of meeting the climb requirements: 2.7% in approach configuration with 1 engine inoperative and 3.2% in landing configuration with all engines operative.
in order to reduce the landing distance to 60% of the effective runway length.
until the central tank is empty in order to cope with the wing and landing gear constraints at landing touchdown.
in order to reach the maximum structural landing weight in less than 15 minutes after activation of the jettisoning system.

variant.question: Which is the highest altitude below which you should not jettison fuel?

options.text: 1 800 m / 6 000 ft AGL
1 500 m / 5 000 ft AGL
1 200 m / 4 000 ft AGL

variant.question: Upon departure from London, the flight encounters a problem which requires a return to the airport for landing and the crew declares an urgency. The aircraft is above its maximum landing mass. To reduce the mass for a safe landing:

options.text: The crew should advice ATC and obtain clearance to an area and a sufficient altitude before starting dumping fuel.
The crew should fly directly on current heading climbing to 4 000 ft to start fuel dumping.
The crew can start fuel dumping immediately at their own discretion.
There is no need to dump fuel and the flight can return immediately for a landing.

variant.question: Upon departure from London, the flight encounters a problem which requires a return to the airport for landing and the crew declares an urgency. The aircraft is above its maximum landing mass. To reduce the mass for a safe landing:

options.text: The crew should advice ATC and obtain clearance to an area and a sufficient altitude before starting dumping fuel.
The crew can start fuel dumping immediately at their own discretion.
There is no need to dump fuel and the flight can return immediately for a landing.
The crew should fly directly on current heading climbing to 4 000 ft to start fuel dumping.

variant.question: Why are large aeroplane required to be equipped with a fuel jettisoning system?

options.text: To reduce aircraft mass after take-off in order to comply with the climb gradients required under CS 25.
An overweight aircraft may damage the runway if the PCN, pavement classification number, is lower than the ACN, aircraft classification number.
It will reduce the risk of fire on landing.
To reduce the mass to Maximum Landing Mass.

variant.question: A commercial jet airplane is experiencing a fuel leak while crossing the North-Atlantic. The pilots are forced to ditch the aircraft. Which of the following configurations is most appropriate, unless the aircraft flight or operations manual state otherwise?

options.text: landing gear up and maximum flaps.
landing gear up and minimum flaps.
landing gear down and maximum flaps.
landing gear down and minimum flaps.

variant.question: If obliged to jettison part of the fuel in flight, it would be better to do so

options.text: in a straight line and at a relatively high flight level.
under flight level 50 (FL50).
in a holding stack, after control clearance.
during final phase of approach.

variant.question: State the requirement for a large aeroplane to be equipped with a fuel jettison system.

options.text: To reduce aircaft mass after take-off in order to comply with the climb gradients required under CS 25
It will reduce the risk of fire on landing.
An overweight aircraft may damage the runway if the PCN, pavement classification number, is lower than the ACN, aircraft classification number.
To reduce the mass to Maximum Landing Mass.
